chapter.title: Equivalence, Implication, and Laws of Logic

section.title: Reading Assignment
section.p: Read sections 3.3 and 3.4 of Applied Discrete Structures. Two propositions may be totally unrelated. For example, It snowed today. and I played chess today. are likely to be unrelated. Yet It snowed today. and I played golf today. are two propositions that are related in that it is unlikely that both are true. In these two sections we introduce the ideas of equivalence and implication, which give us a precise way to talk about how propositions are related.

statement.p: Explain why every proposition implies a tautology.

section.p: Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:

li.p: Construct the truth table for x= (p \land \neg q) \lor (r \land p).
Find an example other than x itself of a proposition generated by p, q, and r that is equivalent to x.
Find an example of a proposition that is not equivalent to x or a contradiction that implies x.
Find an example of a proposition that is not equivalent to x or a tautology that is implied by x.

statement.p: Show that the common fallacy (p\to q) \land \neg p \Rightarrow \neg q is not a law of logic.
Find a proposition that is equivalent to p \lor q and uses only conjunction and negation.

Frankie Fib was telling you what he consumed yesterday afternoon. He tells you, I had either popcorn or raisins. Also, if I had cucumber sandwiches, then I had soda. But I didn't drink soda or tea. Of course you know that Frankie is the worlds worst liar, and everything he says is false. What did Frankie have to eat and drink?
Construct the truth table for (p \rightarrow q) \land (q \rightarrow r) \land (r \rightarrow p). Notice anything about the result?

Suppose that a proposition x generated by p, q and r has the truth table in . How large a set of propositions generated by p, q and r could you possibly compile that all imply x so that none of them are logically equivalent to one another and also not equivalent to x?

solution.p: Any proposition satisfying the conditions that are specified must be false in the cases for which x is false. There are 3 cases where x is true, and any proposition we can list can either be true or false for those cases. There are 2^3 = 8 truth tables that we could construct, but one of them would be equivalent to x so the final answer is 7.

statement.p:
The significance of the Sheffer Stroke is that it is a universal operation in that all other logical operations can be built from it.
Prove that p | q is equivalent to \neg (p \land q).
Prove that \neg p \Leftrightarrow p | p.
Build \land using only the Sheffer Stroke.
Build \lor using only the Sheffer Stroke.

section.title: The Sheffer Stroke
section.p: Another logical operation is the Sheffer Stroke, which is the subject of one of the exercises. It is also referred to as the NAND operation since p \mid q \Leftrightarrow \neg (p \land q)
